msgSnippet: amd64_hacker: Further review of the proposal.  Anything in brackets is my suggested alteration or addition: 1.  What is QuikScript? sec, 2d par. begins:
messageBody:
amd64_hacker:

Further review of the proposal.  Anything in brackets is my suggested alteration or addition:

1.  What is QuikScript? sec, 2d par. begins: "QuikScript has 40 [44] letters, of which 40 are core letters,..."

2.  This would no doubt have been caught:  new typo in Alternate Forms sec., 3d par. "height" mispelled - "e" missing.

3.  My suspicion is that the upper half of S-ee could easily be misread as an H-e or even a T-ea, if one's handwriting is sloppy or hurried. 

I have sat here trying Ch-eer as a half-height, and I don't care for it.  After the initial hook, the pen-stroke is moving from right to left as it descends and going from that directly into a vowel starting at the center writing line just doesn't seem to work very well to me.

I am comfortable with Y-e and Wh-y as half-heights since either of these half-letters clearly cannot be anything else.

4.  Text of Alternate Forms sec. -- Should our desire to have the half-height and alternate forms available be explained more effectively?  If our proposal states that their primary purpose is to increase the speed of handwriting, the powers that be in Unicode may feel these variants serve little purpose in computer-generated text.

In fact, I believe the half-height letters, as well as the alternate forms, will not only aid writing speed, but assist adept readers in reading faster since they produce more distinctive word-scapes as the eye scans along the lines. 

5.  Variant Selectors -- can you explain how this would work?  From what you have written, it seems that the font would normally select whether a full letter or a half-letter or an alternate form would be used in a given context?  Is that correct?  If so, how is that programmed into the font?  For example, would the font know which form of "n" to use based on what letter precedes it?

Previously, we have mapped these alternate forms and half height letters on to the keyboard so that we could choose when we wanted to use them.  My ignorance of how Unicode functions leaves me unclear how having QS encoded in Unicode would change this.  Can you explain that?

I take it that the purpose of the variant selectors was to allow us to override the font's programming if it was needed.  Correct?   But now that seems unnecessary to you.  Does that mean that you believe that having the flexibility to make the choice of half-letters or alternate forms ourselves doesn't seem important to try to include that in the proposal?  Or you just believe the Unicode people, for some reason, would not want that in the encoding of QS?

Paige


amd64_hacker wrote:

Thanks for going over the proposal.

I've fixed the double with typo.

I've rewritten first paragraph of Alternate Forms - I was trying to say
too much in too few words.
I'm still not happy with the new wording though.

The extra half-height characters were due to sloppy copy and pasting on
my part. :(
I've reduced the list to the 'core' alternate forms for the moment.
You mentioned YE and WHY, I've found SEE and CHEER to be quite
acceptable as half heights, are there any others?

I'm reasonably certain that adding extra alternate forms to Unicode
would only be done during a revision to the standard (i.e. from 6.0 to
6.1 or 6.0 to 7.0).
Removing alternate forms is impossible as far as I can see (for good
reasons).

I'm thinking of dropping the Variant Selectors from the proposal.
We'll almost certainly be asked to drop them once it's submitted and I'm
not sure that I can see an argument to defend them with.
I originally thought that there may be occasions when it would be
necessary to explicitly choose one form over another rather than letting
the font choose for us.
For example encoding the string: "The senior form of '<VS1 + UTTER>' is
'<VS2 + UTTER>'."
But the more I think about it the less use I can see for them.

> Regarding your Unicode Proposal. First let me thank you for myself and
> the group for your willingness to put your effort and time into this
> for us all.
>
> I had not found the time to look your proposal in detail previously.
> Here are my thoughts.
>
> First, a couple of minor things:
>
> At the beginning of the proposal, there is a duplicated "with."
>
> A caseless, phonetic, left-to-right alphabet optimised for the
> English language (but still useful for other languages with
> similar sounds) created by (Ronald) Kingsley Read. It is
> the successor to and has much in common with /with/ Shavian.
> Authoritative documentation for it can be found in Ã¢â‚¬Å“The
> QuikScript AlphabetÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½. [emphasis added]
>
> In the following paragraph under "Alternate Forms," I suggest changing
> the word "usually" to "highly" since some letters can be properly
> connected and some cannot.
>
> Many letters have half height or alternate forms in order to help
> speed up writing by reducing the number of strokes and pen lifts.
> The half height and alternate forms are only used in Ã¢â‚¬ËœseniorÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
> QuikScript which is /usually/ cursive. [emphasis added]
>
> Whether a given writer decides to connect any letter to another is his
> choice, but I would consider it improper to extend or change the form
> of a letter in order to make a connection to the next letter possible.
> I believe the only exceptions approved by Read in the QS manual are
> for the letters with alternate forms (N-o and U-tter) and for F-ee,
> M-ay and TH-ey.
>
> The alternate "TH-ey" extends the bottom of the letter upwards to the
> lower writing line to permit connection with the next letter. Read
> terms this an "allowable extension," but it seems to me it should be
> considered an alternate form and listed that way in the proposal.
> While the end stroke of F-ee can also be extended to join the next
> letter, that seems less important to me so, in my opinion, it could be
> left out of the proposal. Of course, others may feel that it should be
> included. I don't know how difficult it is to include these from a
> technical standpoint. If we make provision for some alternate forms,
> then adding a couple more is probably no big deal. In looking back at
> the manual for the first time in a long time, I realize that I almost
> habitually use the alternate form of "M-ay." The standard form seems a
> little more difficult for me to write. That may be lack of practice or
> it may have something to do with being left-handed.
>
> I am confused about your list of letters presented as having
> half-height forms. You list 15 such letters, but the QS manual lists
> only P-ea, T-ea, H-e, D-ay, Z-oo, and W-ay. In addition to those, I
> have used WH-y and Y-e for decades since they work as half-letters
> just as well as the six Read suggested. I had actually forgotten they
> are not listed in the manual as half-letters until Jon Zuck pointed it
> out to me. Since it is clear what letters they are, it just made sense
> to me. Besides, I love the way the half-letters contribute to the
> variety of wordshapes possible in QS. However, you have added seven
> more: F-ee, V-ie, S-ee, SH-e, J'-ai, CH-eer, J-ay. I believe this is
> incorrect. Can you explain how they can be used as half-height forms?
>
> I have never used the two "x" letters as they always struck me as
> outside the spirit of QS -- 1 phoneme to 1 symbol. It was Read's
> stated goal for "x" to "compete" with the TO "x" as if that was
> necessary to avoid people deciding that QS was not viable because of
> two instances where it took two QS symbols when only one was needed in
> TO. Should "x" be included in the proposal. It is in the manual, and I
> guess that if it is coded, then people can choose whether to use it or
> not.
>
> I'm impressed with the rest of the proposal. Thank you again for
> working on this.
>
> Paige
